chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Auric is a tool for analysing financial data, from say accounts payable.

It uses Benford's Law, to look at the regularity of first, second and third digits in amounts. It allows to set and display amounts within certain thresholds. It displays a histogram of values from < 10 through to > 1,000,000 going through powers of 10. It displays repeat values and repeat invoices. Finally, it displays a list of entities with their total spend and number of invoices.
All of these can be viewed on a per entity basis.

chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: Once auric is running, you are presented with the main application window. The first thing you need to do is load in some data. This data takes the form of a simple TAB separated text file. For details of the format of this, see the docs/tmpl.tab file from the source.
Use the file selection dialog to choose the file to load.
Once a file has been selected, you can click the Run button to process this file.
See the following chapters to describe what you are now seeing.

chapter.title: Benford's Law
chapter.para: Benford's Law basically describes the distribution of digits in a number. E.g The number 1 appearing as the first digit of a number should happen about 30.1% of the time, with the first digit being a 9 occuring about 4.5% of the time.
For more details, see this wikipedia page: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benford's_law
In auric we look at the first three digits and have a tab for each, displaying the digit distribution. The display is split into two halves.
The right hand side shows the distribution as a graph. It shows the distribution curve as predicted by Benford's Law in blue and the actual distribution curve of the given data in red.

The left hand side shows the distribution details. Each row shows the digit being examined, the number of times that digit appears in the said location, that number of times as a percentage and the deviation from what was predicted by Benford's Law, negative for less, positive for more.

Below that, we have some other statistics, most of which are self explanatory. The RSF is the Relative Size Factor. This is the maximum value divided by the second maximum value. This is to help find times when an unusually large invoice has gone through compared to the rest.

caption.para: Showing the Benford's Law distribution for the first digit

chapter.title: Centinals
chapter.para: This tab, displays the number of values between certain thresholds. These thresholds can be configured via the preferences window.
It displays the number and percentage for each threshold on the left hand side and on the right it displays this information as a pie chart.

chapter.title: Histogram
chapter.para: This shows the distribution of values from < 10 through to > 1,000,000 going through powers of 10.
On the left hand side it displays the number and percentages for each value and on the right it displays them as a histogram.

caption.para: Showing a histogram of the values

chapter.title: Repeat Values
chapter.para: This shows the top 10 repeated values, showing the value and the number of times it was repeated.

chapter.title: Repeat Invoices
chapter.para: This shows repeat invoices. Currently it just goes by the invoice number to detect duplicates.
If there were any repeat invoices there would be one line per invoice. They would be grouped together by background colour.
You are able to double click on any line, to get more details for those invoices.

chapter.title: Entities
chapter.para: This shows entities in the given data. It displays each entity along with their spend and number of invoices.
Again, you are able to double click a row to get more details.

caption.para: Showing the entities along with their spend and number of invoices

chapter.title: Filtering
chapter.para: For each tab, you can filter by entity, using the entity filter dropdown box at the bottom left hand side of the application.
For the Entities tab you can also filter by spend amount and number of invoices.

chapter.title: Preferences
chapter.para: auric lets you set some preferences. Currently there are two things that can be set

formalpara.title: Centinals
formalpara.para: This lets you set up to five thresholds for the Centinals tab. You can set the values and enable/disable them.

formalpara.title: Decimal Places
formalpara.para: This lets you set the number of decimal places that will be displayed for values. It allows to set from 1 to 6 decimal places. It defaults to 2.

chapter.para: Any changes you make will last just the current session.

caption.para: Options for saving and resetting preferences

formalpara.title: Save
formalpara.para: You can save your preferences, these get saved to ~/.config/auric/prefs and are loaded at startup.

formalpara.title: Reset to Defaults
formalpara.para: This lets you reset the preferences to the application defaults. This will last just for this session, unless you Save them.

formalpara.title: Reset to Config
formalpara.para: This lets you reset the preferences back to your saved configuration.
